questions.text: A teacher demonstrated handwashing procedures to her students. Students repeated the activity later in the day and at home. What kind of learning is going on here? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychomotor

 

The scenario described involves the teacher demonstrating a physical skill (handwashing), which the students then practice and replicate. This type of learning pertains to the acquisition of motor skills and involves physical movement and coordination, making it psychomotor learning.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cognitive: It pertains to mental skills or acquiring knowledge. It involves understanding, reasoning, and thinking processes.

 

Option C. Affective: It relates to feelings, values, attitudes, motivations, and appreciations.

 

Option D. Affective and cognitive: It would involve both emotions/attitudes and mental processes, which is not the primary focus in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychomotor learning involves the acquisition and refinement of motor skills and requires physical movement and coordination. It is demonstrated in this scenario by students learning and practicing the handwashing procedure shown by their teacher.

 

Reference: Milde FK. The Function of Feedback in Psychomotor-Skill Learning. Western Journal of Nursing Research. 1988;10(4):425-434.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway:(INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2-1-3-4-5

 

The correct sequence of the auditory pathway is spiral ganglion - cochlear nucleus - superior olivary nucleus - inferior colliculus - medial geniculate body.

 

2. Spiral Ganglion : The spiral ganglion is situated in Rosenthal's canal and contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve, which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

 

1. Cochlear Nucleus : The cochlear nerve fibers synapse in the cochlear nuclei located in the brainstem.

 

3. Superior Olivary Nucleus : After the cochlear nucleus, the pathway proceeds to the superior olivary nucleus.

 

4. Inferior Colliculus : From the superior olivary nucleus, the auditory signals travel to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

 

5. Medial Geniculate Body : The signals are then relayed to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA).

 

  1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
  2. Cochlear Nucleus
  3. Superior Olivary nucleus
  4. Lateral lemniscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Medial geniculate body
  7. Auditory cortex

questions.text: The most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19 is: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

  • COVID-19 can cause ocular manifestations due to the presence of ACE-2 receptors on the cornea and conjunctiva, which are potential target tissues for SARS-CoV-2.

 

COVID-19:

 

  • Most common ocular symptoms: Dry eye or foreign body sensation, redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.
  • Most common ocular manifestation: Mild follicular conjunctivitis, which can appear as the only sign and symptom of COVID-19.
  • Other less frequent ocular complications: Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, episcleritis, chemosis, and photophobia.
  • Intraocular complications that may occur: Retinal artery occlusions, hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy.
  • Patients with conjunctivitis should undergo a nasopharyngeal RT-PCR test for COVID-19 to rule out systemic infection.
  • Physicians and ophthalmologists should exercise caution when examining patients with conjunctivitis and wear eye-protective gear in addition to face masks and other protective devices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinal vein thrombosis: While COVID-19 can cause thrombotic complications, retinal vein thrombosis is not commonly reported as a primary ocular manifestation of COVID-19.

 

Option B. Viral keratouveitis: There is limited evidence to suggest that COVID-19 directly causes viral keratouveitis. This condition involves inflammation of the cornea and uvea and is more commonly associated with other viruses.

 

Option D. Pseudomembranous conjunctivitis: Pseudomembranes in the context of conjunctivitis are not true membranes but rather a buildup of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and mucus. They can adhere to the conjunctival tissue and may cause a gritty or painful sensation in the eye. Some common causes of pseudomembranous conjunctivitis include:
 

  1. Bacterial Infections: Bacterial conjunctivitis, particularly caused by certain strains of bacteria like Corynebacterium diphtheriae or Streptococcus pneumoniae, can lead to the formation of pseudomembranes.
  2. Viral Infections: In rare cases, certain viruses, such as adenoviruses, can cause pseudomembranous conjunctivitis.
  3. Allergic Reactions: Severe allergic conjunctivitis can lead to the development of pseudomembranes, although this is less common.

 

Treatment for pseudomembranous conjunctivitis typically involves addressing the underlying cause, which may include antibiotics for bacterial infections or antiviral medications for viral infections. In some cases, topical steroids may be prescribed to reduce inflammation and relieve symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation seen in patients with COVID-19, highlighting the virus's ability to affect multiple body systems including the eyes. This underscores the importance of protective measures for healthcare providers, such as wearing masks and eye protection when examining patients suspected of having COVID-19.

choices.text: It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate definition of stress? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain.

 

Stress is a broad term that encompasses the body's physical, emotional, and psychological responses to any demand or threat, whether real or perceived.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External stress: It is inaccurate as not all stress arises from external pressure. Personal thoughts, emotions, and internal conflicts can also induce stress.

 

Option B. Muscle tension: It simplifies stress to just "mental tension." While mental tension can be a component of stress, the definition doesn't capture the breadth of physiological and psychological reactions associated with stress.

 

Option D. Internal strain: It refers to the outcome of the stress rather than the cause or process of stress itself.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Stress can be conceptualized as the body's adaptive response to demands or threats. It's not just a psychological phenomenon; it has physiological correlates as well. Stressors can be external (e.g., environmental pressures) or internal (e.g., illness, or undergoing a medical procedure), and they can be short-lived (acute) or long-term (chronic).

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 2117

questions.text: A 35-year-old man visited the clinic, reporting intermittent episodes of vertigo, a feeling of pressure and fullness in the ear, reduced hearing, and a low-tone roaring tinnitus. What potential clinical condition could be considered as a diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Meniere’s disease

 

The most likely conclusion points to Meniere's disease, alternatively referred to as endolymphatic hydrops.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV): Characterized by brief episodes of vertigo related to changes in head position. It does not typically involve hearing loss or tinnitus.

 

Option C. Labyrinthitis: Involves continuous, not episodic vertigo that usually lasts for days and is accompanied by more pervasive auditory and balance disturbances.

 

Option D. Syncope: Refers to a sudden loss of consciousness and posture, generally caused by a decrease in blood flow to the brain, not typically associated with auditory symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meniere’s disease is a complex inner ear disorder that requires careful management to control symptoms and prevent progression. Treatment strategies focus on relieving the symptoms and, in severe cases, may involve surgical interventions to reduce the endolymphatic pressure or decompress the endolymphatic sac. Patients benefit from a multi-disciplinary approach involving audiologists, otolaryngologists, and sometimes neurologists.

questions.text: A 60-year-old individual with diabetes presented with intense ear pain and otorrhea that did not improve with antibiotics. During the examination, granulation tissue was observed in the external auditory canal (EAC), and the person also exhibited facial nerve palsy. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Malignant otitis externa

 

Severe otalgia in an elderly diabetic patient with granulation tissue in the external ear canal points to a diagnosis of Malignant (Necrotizing) otitis externa.

 

ETIOLOGY – More common in elderly, diabetic and immunocompromised patients.

 

CAUSATIVE ORGANISM - Pseudomonas aeruginosa (most common), Staphylococcus aureus, Proteus species, and fungi.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES

 

  • Excruciating ear pain
  • Granulations in the ear canal
  • Facial paralysis is common.
  • Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple lower cranial nerve palsies
  • Anteriorly, infection spreads to temporomandibular fossa
  • Posteriorly to the mastoid and medially into the middle ear and petrous bone.

 

DIAGNOSIS

 

  • Gallium-67 is more useful in diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. It is taken up by monocytes and reticuloendothelial cells, and is indicative of soft tissue infection. It can be repeated every 3 weeks to monitor the disease and response to treatment.          
  • Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection but test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease.

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Control of diabetes
  • Aural toilet
  • Antibiotic treatment against causative organism, which in most commonly P. aeruginosa (or any other causative organism) for 6-8 weeks.
  • Antibiotics commonly used are anti-pseudomonal antibiotics ; Third-generation cephalosporins ; Ciprofloxacin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otomycosis: Typically presents with itching and a fungal ear discharge, without the severe pain or systemic complications seen in MOE.

 

Option B. Serous otitis media: Involves fluid accumulation in the middle ear, generally without the severe external ear pain or granulation tissue.

 

Option D. Eczematous otitis externa: Characterized by itching and skin changes, but not the deep infection or severe complications associated with MOE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignant otitis externa is a critical condition requiring aggressive management due to its potential to cause widespread damage and severe complications, including cranial nerve involvement. Prompt and appropriate treatment is essential to prevent potentially life-threatening outcomes.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 55

questions.text: A 2-year-old child’s father brought him for checkup. On examination, there was white pupillary reflex. USG findings shows intraocular mass with calcification in the eye. There is a family history of enucleation. What is the diagnosis?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Retinoblastoma

 

Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina that typically presents in young children. It often presents with a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) and may be associated with an intraocular mass with calcification. There is also a familial predisposition to retinoblastoma, which is indicated by the family history of enucleation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exudative retinal detachment: Exudative retinal detachment is a condition where fluid accumulates under the retina, leading to detachment. It is not typically associated with a white pupillary reflex or intraocular mass with calcification.

 

Option B. Pediatric tuberculosis: Pediatric tuberculosis can affect various organs, including the eyes, but it usually presents with other signs and symptoms such as fever, cough, and weight loss. It is unlikely to present with a white pupillary reflex and intraocular mass with calcification.

 

Option C. Retinopathy of prematurity: Retinopathy of prematurity is a condition affecting premature infants and is characterized by abnormal blood vessel growth in the retina. It does not typically present with a white pupillary reflex or intraocular mass with calcification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma should be considered in a young child with a white pupillary reflex and intraocular mass with calcification, especially in the presence of a family history of enucleation.

questions.text: Extra row of eyelashes behind the grey line is called as? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Distichiasis

 

Distichiasis refers to the additional row of eyelashes behind the grey line. It may happen as a result of inherited or acquired factors.

 

The cornea may become irritated by these lashes. The treatment involves separating the lids and applying cryotherapy to the hair follicles' bases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichiasis: Refers to the misdirection of eyelashes that grow inward towards the eye, causing irritation and potential damage to the cornea. The lid margin remains in its normal position.

 

Option C. Tylosis: Refers to the thickening of the tarsal plate, often associated with chronic inflammation and lid margin disease, but not related to an extra row of eyelashes.

 

Option D. Madarosis: Refers to the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows, which can be due to various causes including trauma, systemic diseases, and dermatologic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Distichiasis is the condition where an extra row of eyelashes grows behind the normal lash line, often leading to corneal irritation and requiring treatment such as cryotherapy or electrolysis to prevent complications.

questions.text: A husband and wife presented to the outpatient department with complaints of the husband's premature ejaculation, which is leading to frequent conflicts between them. Which of the following non-pharmacological techniques is most appropriate for treatment? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squeeze Technique

 

For the management of premature ejaculation, the Squeeze Technique is a specific non-pharmacological method that is often recommended. This technique involves sexual stimulation until the individual is close to ejaculation. At that point, the partner squeezes the shaft of the penis (coronal ridge of glans) for several seconds, which can delay ejaculation. This process is repeated several times before ejaculation is allowed to occur. The Squeeze Technique helps in increasing the time before ejaculation and is directly targeted at managing premature ejaculation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sensate Focus Technique: While this technique, which involves non-genital pleasuring, can be helpful in reducing performance anxiety and improving sexual communication, it is not specifically designed for the treatment of premature ejaculation. It is useful for erectile dysfunction.

 

Option C. Exposure and Response Prevention: This is a technique used primarily in the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder and is not typically employed for premature ejaculation.

 

Option D. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): CBT can be useful for addressing underlying psychological issues contributing to sexual dysfunction, but it is a more general approach and not as specifically targeted for premature ejaculation as the Squeeze Technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Squeeze Technique is a specific non-pharmacological method effective in the management of premature ejaculation. It involves squeezing the penis before the point of ejaculation to delay it and can be repeated several times to increase the time before ejaculation.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 531.
